trial_identification.studytitle: Aggressive mobilisation following fragment specific fixation of distal radius fractures
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Aggressive mobilisation following fragment specific fixation of distal radius fractures improves functional outcome of the wrist joint

interventions.interventions: Aggressive physiotherapy is the intervention group. From day 1 post operatively they will receive intense encouragement both active and passive to achieve increased range of motion and grip strength. Both will attend 1-3 sessions per week with encouragement to do home exercises. Treatment will be for 6 months
interventions.comparator: Regular physiotherapy is the control group. They will receive a more moderate form of the aggressive regime.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Function of the wrist joint. We will use specific wrist scores "The Functional Index" (FI) and "Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation" (PRWE).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Tested at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Range of motion and grip strength tested

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Must be english speaking, of sound mind, to consent. fracture pattern must be complex, requiring at least 2 incisions and at least 2 forms of internal fixation (according to the staff orthoapedic surgeon).
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Non -english speaking, not of sound mind to consent, fracture not severe enough to require two forms of internal fixation.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To investigate whether aggressive physiotherapy achieves a better functional outcome than regular physiotherapy after operations for wrist fractures. The subjects are blinded. The Physiotherapist is not blinded. The surgeon is also blinded however this fact is not as much of a cornerstone to the study as the blinding status of the patients and the physiotherapist.
